description.narrative: Gemensamt projekt mellan UNDP, DPKO och DPA för att stärka samordning och planering av FN:s transitionsprocesser på landnivå. Expertstöd till länder, träning och utformning av styrning och system på HQ-nivå ingår i projektet.

Joint project between UNDP, DPKO and DPA to improve UN Mission transition planning and implementation. Expert support to country level, training and framing of guidance and coordination at HQ level included in the project.

The overall objective of the project is that the UN strengthens its capacity, and that of the host country, to manage UN transitions (first and foremost from UN Peacekeeping Mission to UN Country Team presence) so that prospects are strengthened for resilience and sustained peace in post-conflict countries. UN transitions are to be undertaken proactively, gradually, seamlessly and in coordination with host governments. The Project also contributes to four key objectives of the UN reforms: (1) prioritize prevention (2) strengthen field focus (3) deliver on the 2030 Agenda (4) and breaking down the silos.

sector.narrative: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution

tag.narrative: 10.3 - Ensure equal opportunity and reduce inequalities of outcome, including by eliminating discriminatory laws, policies and practices and promoting appropriate legislation, policies and action in this regard.

10.3 - Säkerställa lika möjligheter och minska förekomsten av ojämlika utfall, bland annat genom att avskaffa diskriminerande lagstiftning, politik och praxis och främja lagstiftning, politik och åtgärder av lämpligt slag i detta hänseende.
16.1 - Avsevärt minska alla former av våld och dödligt våld överallt.
16.1 - Significantly reduce all forms of violence and related death rates everywhere.
16.3 - Främja rättssäkerheten på nationell och internationell nivå samt säkerställa lika tillgång till rättvisa för alla.
16.3 - Promote the rule of law at the national and international levels and ensure equal access to justice for all.
16.5 - Substantially reduce corruption and bribery in all their forms.
16.5 - Väsentligt minska alla former av korruption och mutor.
16.7 - Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.
16.7 - Säkerställa ett lyhört, inkluderande, deltagandebaserat och representativt beslutsfattande på alla nivåer.

16.a - Strengthen relevant national institutions, including through international cooperation, for building capacity at all levels, in particular in developing countries, to prevent violence and combat terrorism and crime.

16.a - Stärka berörda nationella institutioner, bland annat genom internationellt samarbete, i syfte att bygga upp kapacitet på alla nivåer, i synnerhet i utvecklingsländerna, för att förebygga våld och bekämpa terrorism och brottslighet.
5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.
5.5 - Tillförsäkra kvinnor fullt och faktiskt deltagande och lika möjligheter till ledarskap på alla beslutsnivåer i det politiska, ekonomiska och offentliga livet.

description.narrative: Throughout the reporting period, the project has managed to achieve a noticeable shift among UN entities away from a focus limited to mission withdrawal and towards a more proactive and forward-looking approach that places emphasis on consolidating peacebuilding gains and sustaining peace beyond mission withdrawal. Direct country support has improved the way in which UN transition processes are planned and managed in the DRC, Guinea-Bissau, Haiti, Mali and Sudan. Despite these achievements, capacities for integrated transition planning and management have not been sufficiently institutionalized. At the same time, the need for this support has never been greater, especially considering the complex contexts in which upcoming UN transitions will take place. In Guinea-Bissau, a transition workshop provided the necessary momentum for integrated transition planning. As a result, a coordination task force was set up that has guided the transition planning at country level and a comprehensive transition calendar was developed that identifies joint peacebuilding priorities in the country and outlines a course of action to capacitate the UNCT and national stakeholders to address these beyond mission withdrawal. Despite the initial progress made, the political instability, the change in UN senior leadership at country level, and the Covid-19 outbreak has slowed down the implementation of the transition calendar and has made it difficult to ensure full national ownership in the planning process. For Haiti, the following results were achieved; 1. Seamless transition: The management of the MINUJUSTH drawdown and the start-up of BINUH was planned in a manner that focused on having adequate capacities on the ground to ensure continuous UN support to key national processes, primarily the political dialogue and rule of law reforms. 2. Inclusive transition planning and implementation: with the Project’s support, all the planning processes were based on close collaboration between the UNCT and mission, as well as key offices at headquarters. The Project played a liaison role to bring the different UN entities together during the process. 3. High-level guidance to the system: the SG Directive on Haiti provided clear guidance on all transition deliverables not only for the start-up of BINUH but for the preparedness of the whole system for the transition. 4. Close collaboration DPPA/DPO with DCO regional and HQ structures allowed for the articulation of a common vision on peace, security and development objectives and enabled preparing the ground for close integration between BINUH and Country team (e.g., through benchmarks and the CCA process). 5. Peacebuilding: The political efforts to convince Haiti to request access to the PBF and the subsequent integrated planning process led by PBSO and drawing on national priorities allowed for the UNCT access funds for key peace building priorities. Liberia (UNMIL) was where the UN Transitions Project started. While the Peacebuilding Plan identified the substantive priorities intended to drive the UN’s work during the transition, the capacity mapping exercise assessed the extent to which the UN in Liberia could undertake those commitments post-UNMIL. Together, these concretely shaped transition planning processes at UN headquarters and in the field.The transition to a strengthened resident coordinator’s office – with a political, peace, and development analysis unit, along with a stand-alone office for the Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights (OHCHR) – is an innovation and a test case for the ongoing UN development reforms. The post-UNMIL country team configuration is supported by multilateral partners, a multi-partner trust fund, and the UN Peacebuilding Office. The co-financing of a position to manage the MPTF and resource mobilization efforts has been a strategic initiative for the project as it highlights the message that a UN transition does not end with the exit of a mission but continues for a number of years afterwards. Financing gaps for residual peacebuilding priorities are a key challenge for the reconfigured UN presence after mission withdrawal and as such need continued support from the UN system.Although considerable challenges remain and both the Liberian government as well as remaining UN actors struggle to generate resources to sustain peace, the UN transition in many ways can be considered a success and much can be learned from Liberia for future transitions. For Sudan, the following has been achieved; 1; The Visioning Exercise: in September 2019 the government, the UN and key partners met in Khartoum to reach a common understanding of the challenges and opportunities and identify priorities for the success of the national transition. This exercise provided a substantive chapeau for the transition process and enhanced national ownership over it.2; The State Liaison Functions: this mechanism, which has made mission programmatic funds and staff available to UNAFPs so that they can enhance their engagement around peacebuilding priorities, has been heralded as one of the most important innovations in peacekeeping in the last twenty years by the Effectiveness of Peace Operations Network (EPON)4.3; Partners Forum for Sudan: the donor conference, held in Berlin in June 2020 and resulting in an announced $1.8 billion in assistance to Sudan. Beyond the much-needed financial resources, the event provided the president with political capital for the national transition. At the global policy level, the project has organised transitions workshop from the relevant countries for sharing of experiences, a UNDP Resident Representative retreat on the topic, a joint transition workshop with the global focal point for the rule of law, and integrated transition sessions in other UN trainings and workshops. The project has also produced many papers, fact sheets, studies and reports on the topic of UN transitions in order to capture lessons learnt and good practices. Regarding sustainability and the integration of transitions capacity in UN institutions, the project has contributed to making transitions one of the most prominent items on the agenda of Member States, UN leadership, as well as relevant policy and research institutions. The Project has, for example, strengthened its engagement with the Executive Office of the Secretary General (EOSG) and is providing regular briefings to the EC/DC. It has also stepped up advocacy with Member States and has collaborated with other intergovernmental organizations such as OECD and the g7+, as well as research institutions such as UNU, IPI, and CIC. This work has resulted in an increased awareness of the importance of transitions for sustaining peace. The Project has also engaged closer with The Peacebuilding Fund, which has created a transition financing window.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
